page.title: 16Language in Ballantrae.
page.content: The accent is typical of the West of Scotland though some vowel sounds are broadened.Standard English is widely spoken as the reduction and replace- ment of traditional occupations have caused the use of the vernacular to diminish.Local population changes due to movement and the introduction of persons retiring from elsewhere also affect the language used.The vernacular is heard mainly among older residents, farmers using the jargon of their trade,but young people are heard using idiomatic words and phrases when in conversation among themselves.Radio and TV have affected children's speech as they are exposed to these from an early age but Burns Federation School Competitions for singing,reciting Scots songs and poems keep alive the knowledge of Ayrshire idioms.
